articles.title: How to turn Africa’s young demographic potential into a collective power
articles.summary: The African youth, an exploding population, needs support and programs to turn their potential into economic power.
articles.content:
In public spaces, transport, and the media, we see the challenges facing an increasingly elderly population: increased healthcare needs, failure to adapt infrastructure, public transport, and housing to help maintain their independence. A few weeks ago, I travelled to Japan, where I saw firsthand how the aging population isn’t just an abstract statistic.

In 2023, the Japanese population had a life expectancy of over 80 for both men and women, with those over 65 accounting for 29 percent of the population, and those under 15 accounting for 11 percent. Comparatively, for the same time period in Senegal, those over 65 accounted for 3.8 percent of the population, and those under 15 accounted for 39 percent.

In Japan, in addition to this observation, I witnessed the effective social and spatial adaptation of infrastructure and services to support this age group: infrastructure designed for limited mobility, health devices, jobs dedicated to elder care, and even the use of technology to aid them in their daily tasks.

However, in Africa, we tend to hear more about the population boom. After all, this continent now has the world’s youngest population. According to a UNICEF report published in 2023, by 2050, Africa will account for around 41 percent of all global births — about 40 percent of all children under five, and 35 percent of all adolescents. This young population has the potential to be a massive force for change.

Promising initiatives to combat major challenges

When young people are supported, they demonstrate their independence and innovation. Such is the case in Kenya, where the Nairobi technology hubs power the “Silicon Savannah,” and in Tunisia, where the startup ecosystem is integrated into public employment policies. In Rwanda, the investment policy in digital technology and services has reduced young graduate unemployment by almost 10 percent over the past decade

However, as education remains a privilege, this potential is largely underutilized. According to UNESCO, more than 98 million school-aged children and young people are out of school in Sub-Saharan Africa. For 15- to 17-year-olds, the school dropout rate exceeds 50 percent, including in technical courses, and is even higher for girls. As such, millions of young people leave the system without the necessary skills to become agents of development.

Only strong political will can reverse that trend, as shown in Ghana, where the Free Senior High School program, combining free access, scholarship policies, and facility improvements, increased secondary school enrolment by 69 percent between 2017 and 2022.

Incompatibility between training and employment

Sustainable development cannot be limited to access to education; it is still necessary to utilize the acquired skills. Many African education systems remain out of touch with the labor market needs. Technical, vocational, and digital education remains inadequate and often undervalued.

The consequences are clear. Every year, 10 to 12 million young people enter the African labor market, but only 3.7 million formal jobs are created. Many turn to informal employment, with precarious incomes and no social protection. This lack of productivity hampers growth, weakens social cohesion, and often fuels migration.

According to the National Bureau of Statistics, more than 92 percent of workers in Nigeria are now part of the informal work industry. This percentage is even greater among young people. In a study by the International Labor Organization (ILO), 98 percent of employed young men and 99 percent of employed young women report being in informal employment.

In South Africa, informal employment accounts for a significant segment of the economy. According to trade unions, this sector accounts for around 27 percent of the workforce.

However, alternatives exist. In Somalia, social entrepreneur and Aspen Institute member Mohamed Ali Dini founded the IFTIN Foundation. This program trains and employs young people, offering them mental health support to overcome the trauma of war and reintegrate into society. This type of integrated approach — employment, health, and resilience — exemplifies how Africa can transform its young people into agents of reconstruction.

Among these young people, girls are the ones who experience multiple forms of discrimination: limited access to education, child marriages, teenage pregnancies, and sexual abuse. According to UNICEF, more than one in eight girls in Sub-Saharan Africa has experienced a form of sexual abuse during childhood.

And yet, young women are powerful agents of change. In Senegal, initiatives like Senegaleses in Tech or Jokalante train hundreds of young women in digital and coding professions. These often civil-society-led programs show that investing in women’s education and economic independence has a positive effect on society as a whole: higher incomes, reduced inequalities, improved health, and family stability. Empowering young women is, therefore, a key sustainable development strategy.

The African Development Bank’s (AfDB) projections indicate that Africa’s working population will increase from about 56 percent to 63 percent by 2050. If this transition is well managed, it could become a source of prosperity. But without massive investment in education, health, training, and formal employment, this advantage could become a disadvantage: a large but marginalized youth population.

Some countries have shown the way. In Ethiopia, the Youth Revolving Fund has funded over 200,000 youth entrepreneurial projects since 2019. When built on a coherent national vision, these programs can sustainably reduce youth unemployment and rebuild social trust.

Well-defined development priorities

Various strategies are required to put this potential into force. The first step involves fundamentally reforming education systems to meet the current needs of local economies. The programs must include digital skills, green occupations, sustainable agriculture, craftsmanship, and small business management. Ensuring universal access to secondary education, especially for girls, requires targeted scholarships, appropriate infrastructure, and local education policies.

Secondly, it is vital to create decent jobs that offer young people tangible prospects. This means supporting entrepreneurship with accessible funding mechanisms, mentorship, and greater integration in local and regional markets. Governments and partners must also foster investments in growing sectors, such as technology, light industry, and renewable energy.

Health and social protection are another indispensable asset. Youth policies must include reproductive health, mental health, and social security. Particular attention should also be paid to the protection of young women from violence and discrimination, which hinders their economic and social participation.

Lastly, youth participation and leadership must be central to public action. Young people, and young women in particular, must be included in decision-making spaces on all levels: local, national, and regional. Fostering inclusive leadership, rooted in community realities, is a prerequisite for building resilient and equitable societies.

I often think back on what I saw in Japan, an aging society that, paradoxically, values young people as a rare commodity. There, they want more young people, they look for them, train them, and listen to them. In Africa, we have the opposite, an abundance of young people who are rarely valued. We have the world’s greatest demographic treasure, and yet we don’t make it a priority.
articles.reasoning: The article highlights Africa's young population as a significant potential force for economic and social development, emphasizing successful initiatives in education, entrepreneurship, and social support that empower youth and particularly young women. It discusses broad, meaningful impacts on society and the economy, with detailed examples and policy recommendations, making it an inspiring story about harnessing demographic potential for positive change.
articles.personality_title: Africa’s young population offers a path to future growth with the right support
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Africa has the youngest population in the world, with a large number of children and teenagers. This contrasts with countries like Japan, where many people are elderly. While Africa’s young people have great potential, many face challenges like limited access to education and jobs.

**What happened** – Several African countries have started programs to help young people succeed. For example, Kenya’s technology hubs support young innovators, Tunisia integrates startups into job policies, and Rwanda’s focus on digital skills has lowered youth unemployment. In Ghana, free secondary education has helped more students stay in school. Meanwhile, organizations like Somalia’s IFTIN Foundation train youth and provide mental health support.

**Impact** – These efforts show that when young people get education, skills, and support, they can drive economic growth and social progress. Young women, often facing extra challenges, are becoming leaders through programs that teach digital skills. Without these efforts, many young Africans end up in informal jobs with little security, which limits growth and increases poverty.

**What's next step** – To fully benefit from its youth, Africa needs to improve education systems to match job market needs, create more formal jobs, and provide health and social protections. Governments should include young people in decision-making and invest in sectors like technology and renewable energy. Expanding support for girls and young women is also key.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Africa’s large young population can become a powerful force for development if given education, jobs, and support tailored to their needs.
articles.personality_title_fr: La jeunesse africaine, une clé pour la croissance future avec le bon soutien
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – L’Afrique possède la population la plus jeune au monde, avec beaucoup d’enfants et d’adolescents. Cela contraste avec des pays comme le Japon, où la majorité est âgée. Bien que les jeunes africains aient un grand potentiel, beaucoup rencontrent des difficultés comme l’accès limité à l’éducation et à l’emploi.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Plusieurs pays africains ont lancé des programmes pour aider les jeunes à réussir. Par exemple, les hubs technologiques au Kenya soutiennent les jeunes innovateurs, la Tunisie intègre les startups dans les politiques d’emploi, et le Rwanda a réduit le chômage des jeunes grâce aux compétences numériques. Au Ghana, l’éducation secondaire gratuite a augmenté le nombre d’élèves. En Somalie, la fondation IFTIN forme des jeunes et offre un soutien psychologique.

**Impact** – Ces initiatives montrent que lorsque les jeunes ont accès à l’éducation, aux compétences et au soutien, ils peuvent stimuler la croissance économique et le progrès social. Les jeunes filles, souvent plus défavorisées, deviennent des leaders grâce à des programmes de formation numérique. Sans ces efforts, beaucoup de jeunes travaillent dans l’informel, ce qui limite le développement et accroît la pauvreté.

**Prochaine étape** – Pour tirer pleinement parti de sa jeunesse, l’Afrique doit améliorer ses systèmes éducatifs pour répondre aux besoins du marché du travail, créer plus d’emplois formels et offrir des protections sociales et sanitaires. Les gouvernements doivent inclure les jeunes dans la prise de décisions et investir dans des secteurs comme la technologie et les énergies renouvelables. Soutenir davantage les filles et les jeunes femmes est aussi essentiel.

**Phrase clé** – La grande population jeune d’Afrique peut devenir une force puissante de développement si elle reçoit une éducation, des emplois et un soutien adaptés à ses besoins.
articles.personality_title_es: La juventud africana, clave para el crecimiento futuro con el apoyo adecuado
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – África tiene la población más joven del mundo, con muchos niños y adolescentes. Esto contrasta con países como Japón, donde la mayoría son personas mayores. Aunque los jóvenes africanos tienen un gran potencial, enfrentan desafíos como el acceso limitado a la educación y al empleo.

**Qué pasó** – Varios países africanos han iniciado programas para ayudar a los jóvenes a tener éxito. Por ejemplo, los centros tecnológicos en Kenia apoyan a jóvenes innovadores, Túnez integra startups en políticas de empleo y Ruanda ha reducido el desempleo juvenil con habilidades digitales. En Ghana, la educación secundaria gratuita aumentó la matrícula escolar. En Somalia, la fundación IFTIN capacita a jóvenes y ofrece apoyo mental.

**Impacto** – Estos esfuerzos muestran que cuando los jóvenes reciben educación, habilidades y apoyo, pueden impulsar el crecimiento económico y el progreso social. Las jóvenes, que enfrentan más desafíos, se están convirtiendo en líderes gracias a programas de formación digital. Sin estos apoyos, muchos jóvenes trabajan en empleos informales, lo que limita el desarrollo y aumenta la pobreza.

**Próximo paso** – Para aprovechar plenamente a su juventud, África debe mejorar los sistemas educativos para que coincidan con las necesidades laborales, crear más empleos formales y proporcionar protección social y de salud. Los gobiernos deben incluir a los jóvenes en la toma de decisiones e invertir en sectores como tecnología y energías renovables. También es clave ampliar el apoyo a niñas y jóvenes mujeres.

**Conclusión en una frase** – La gran población joven de África puede ser una fuerza poderosa para el desarrollo si recibe educación, empleo y apoyo adaptados a sus necesidades.

articles.title: Press release - Protect copyrighted work used by generative AI, say Legal Affairs MEPs
articles.summary: Access to high quality data to train generative AI in the EU should go hand in hand with fair remuneration for the creative sector.Committee on Legal Affairs Source : © European Union, 2026 - EP
articles.content:
On Wednesday, Legal Affairs Committee MEPs adopted a series of proposals to ensure full transparency and fair remuneration of rightsholders for the use of copyrighted work by generative artificial intelligence (genAI), by 17 votes in favour, 3 against, and with 2 abstentions.

Remuneration for use of protected work

MEPs want EU copyright law to apply to all generative AI systems available on the EU market, regardless where the training takes place. Since genAI relies on and reproduces protected content, MEPs want full transparency about its use, including a list of each copyrighted work used and detailed records of crawling activities by AI providers and deployers. Failure to comply with transparency requirements could be tantamount to infringement of copyright, for which AI providers could bear legal consequences.

MEPs also demand fair remuneration for the use of copyrighted content by AI to ensure that the EU’s creative and cultural sector can thrive in the AI age. They call on the Commission to examine whether such remuneration could also apply to past use, while rejecting the idea of a global licence allowing providers to train their genAI systems in exchange for a flat-rate payment.

Protecting the news media sector and individual rights

In the report, MEPs call on the Commission and member states to protect media pluralism, which is threatened by AI systems aggregating the news in a selective manner, diverting their traffic and revenues. They believe that the news media sector must have full control over the use of its content for training AI systems, including the possibility to refuse such use. MEPs also urge the Commission to ensure adequate remuneration for this use.

MEPs believe that content fully generated by AI should not be protected by copyright. They call for measures to protect individuals against the dissemination of manipulated and AI-generated content and for an obligation on digital service providers to act against such illegal use.

Possibility for rightsholders to prevent their work from being used by AI

MEPs call for new rules to address the licensing of copyrighted material for use by genAI and call on the Commission to facilitate the establishment of voluntary collective licensing agreements per sector accessible to all, including individual creators and small and medium-sized enterprises. They also ask the Commission to explore tools allowing rightsholders to prevent their work from being used by general-purpose AI systems.

Quote

Following the vote, rapporteur Axel Voss (EPP, DE) said: “Generative AI must not operate outside the rule of law. If copyrighted works are used to train AI systems, creators are entitled to transparency, legal certainty, and fair compensation. Innovation cannot come at the expense of copyright, both can and must coexist. Clear and enforceable rules are key to ensuring Europe’s technological sovereignty. Our aim is to foster innovation while safeguarding the core principles of intellectual property.”

Next steps

This own initiative report will be put to a Parliament vote in plenary in March.

Background

The report seeks to answer key legal questions about the interplay between genAI and copyright, including how to ensure transparency, consent and fair remuneration of creators and rightsholders when their protected works are used in the generation, dissemination and distribution of AI outputs.
articles.reasoning: The article reports on a significant legislative initiative by the EU Parliament to ensure transparency and fair remuneration for creators whose copyrighted works are used to train generative AI systems. This protects the rights of a broad group of creators and the cultural sector, promoting fairness and legal certainty in the AI era. The impact is broad, affecting the entire EU creative sector and fostering innovation while safeguarding intellectual property rights.
articles.personality_title: EU lawmakers push for fair pay and transparency in AI use of copyrighted works
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The European Union is working on rules to manage how generative artificial intelligence (genAI) uses copyrighted content. genAI systems learn from lots of existing work, like books, music, or art, but this raises questions about creators’ rights and fair payment.

**What happened** – On Wednesday, members of the EU Parliament’s Legal Affairs Committee voted to support new proposals. These would require AI companies to be clear about which copyrighted works they use to train their systems. The rules also say creators should get fair payment when their work is used. The vote passed with 17 in favor, 3 against, and 2 abstentions.

**Impact** – This decision is important because it protects creators like writers, musicians, and journalists in the digital age. It ensures they are paid when their work helps train AI. It also asks for strong transparency, so creators know exactly how their work is used. This helps keep the creative industry healthy while AI grows.

**What's next step** – The full European Parliament will vote on these rules in March. If approved, the European Commission will work on ways to make sure creators can choose whether or not AI can use their work. They will also look at fair ways to pay for past uses of content.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The EU is taking clear steps to protect creators’ rights and ensure fair payment as artificial intelligence learns from copyrighted work.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les députés européens réclament une rémunération équitable et plus de transparence pour l’utilisation des œuvres protégées par l’IA
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – L’Union européenne élabore des règles pour encadrer l’utilisation des œuvres protégées par l’intelligence artificielle générative (IA générative). Ces systèmes apprennent à partir d’œuvres existantes comme des livres, de la musique ou des œuvres d’art, ce qui soulève des questions sur les droits des créateurs et une rémunération juste.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Mercredi, les membres de la commission des affaires juridiques du Parlement européen ont voté en faveur de nouvelles propositions. Celles-ci obligeraient les entreprises d’IA à être transparentes sur les œuvres protégées utilisées pour entraîner leurs systèmes. Les règles prévoient aussi que les créateurs soient justement rémunérés pour l’usage de leurs œuvres. Le vote s’est conclu par 17 voix pour, 3 contre et 2 abstentions.

**Impact** – Cette décision protège les créateurs comme les écrivains, musiciens et journalistes à l’ère numérique. Elle garantit qu’ils soient payés lorsque leurs œuvres servent à entraîner l’IA. Elle demande également une grande transparence, pour que les créateurs sachent précisément comment leurs œuvres sont utilisées. Cela aide à préserver la santé du secteur créatif pendant la croissance de l’IA.

**Prochaine étape** – Le Parlement européen entier votera ces règles en mars. Si elles sont approuvées, la Commission européenne travaillera à permettre aux créateurs de choisir s’ils autorisent ou non l’utilisation de leurs œuvres par l’IA. Elle étudiera aussi des moyens justes de rémunérer l’utilisation passée des contenus.

**Phrase clé** – L’UE prend des mesures claires pour protéger les droits des créateurs et garantir une rémunération équitable alors que l’intelligence artificielle apprend à partir d’œuvres protégées.
articles.personality_title_es: Los diputados europeos exigen pago justo y transparencia en el uso de obras protegidas por IA
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La Unión Europea está creando normas para controlar cómo la inteligencia artificial generativa (IA generativa) usa obras protegidas por derechos de autor. Estos sistemas aprenden a partir de trabajos existentes, como libros, música o arte, lo que genera dudas sobre los derechos de los creadores y el pago justo.

**Qué pasó** – El miércoles, los miembros del Comité de Asuntos Jurídicos del Parlamento Europeo apoyaron nuevas propuestas. Estas exigirían a las empresas de IA ser transparentes sobre qué obras protegidas usan para entrenar sus sistemas. También establecen que los creadores deben recibir un pago justo cuando se use su trabajo. La votación terminó con 17 a favor, 3 en contra y 2 abstenciones.

**Impacto** – Esta decisión protege a creadores como escritores, músicos y periodistas en la era digital. Asegura que reciban pago cuando su trabajo ayuda a entrenar la IA. También exige transparencia para que los creadores sepan cómo se usa su trabajo. Esto ayuda a mantener sano el sector creativo mientras crece la IA.

**Próximo paso** – El Parlamento Europeo completo votará estas reglas en marzo. Si se aprueban, la Comisión Europea trabajará para que los creadores puedan decidir si permiten que la IA use su trabajo. También estudiará formas justas de pagar por el uso pasado de contenido.

**Resumen en una frase** – La UE avanza para proteger los derechos de los creadores y asegurar un pago justo mientras la inteligencia artificial aprende de obras protegidas.

articles.title: Study: Over 70 percent of citizens support EU membership, with a slight increase in Euroscepticism
articles.summary: The EU continues to be regarded as the most important and most influential ally of the country, and in the context of the current geopolitical turmoil it is evident that citizens are leaning toward the alternative or option in which they see the greatest security, safety, and prospects.
articles.content:
The EU continues to be regarded as the most important and most influential ally of the country, and in the context of the current geopolitical turmoil it is evident that citizens are leaning toward the alternative or option in which they see the greatest security, safety, and prospects.

Skopje – A total of 71 percent of the population support EU membership, which is almost ten percent more compared to the previous year, according to the results of the research “Analysis of Public Opinion on the Accession of North Macedonia to the European Union (2014 – 2025)” by the Institute for Democracy – “Societas Civilis” – Skopje, presented today in the Parliament.

The key findings of the research show that Eurosceptic attitudes are slightly increasing – from 11 to 14 percent of the population are expressing Euroscepticism, while the number of undecided and apathetic respondents has significantly decreased over the past year.

The long-standing gap in support for EU membership between the two largest ethnic groups – ethnic Macedonians and ethnic Albanians – has decreased. A total of 71 percent of ethnic Macedonians support the country’s candidacy for EU membership, which represents an increase of 15 percent compared to the previous year.

Among ethnic Albanians, strong support for the country’s aspirations for EU membership continues to be expressed. This support is maintained in 2025, with 76 percent of respondents from this group declaring themselves positively. However, this percentage is 8 percent lower compared to the previous year.

According to the research, 40 percent of the population believe that the country is ready to become a member state, and slightly more than 60 percent of the population believe that progress has been made in the accession process over the past year. The research shows that 46 percent of the population believe that obstructions from neighboring countries are the biggest obstacle to North Macedonia’s progress towards EU membership.

The number of respondents who believe that the country will become an EU member in the next 3–5 years has increased and in 2025 stands at 30 percent, while a relatively high share of the population (19 percent) remains pessimistic about North Macedonia’s prospects for EU membership.

Anamarija Velinovska, researcher at the Center for European Integrations at IDSCS, emphasized that the first part of the research shows how citizens view the process from within and what the necessary steps are.

– What we have been following for three years now is that support for the constitutional amendments remains at 24 percent and here there is an obvious gap between ethnic Macedonians and ethnic Albanians. In fact, it shows that 57 percent of ethnic Albanians are in favor of constitutional amendments, while only 11 percent of Macedonian respondents are in favor of constitutional amendments – said Velinovska.

Marko Troshanovski, president of ICDS, emphasized that for the first time this year, after several years of decline, support for the EU has recorded a significant increase and exceeds 70 percent.

– What is also interesting is that the number of those citizens who think that Macedonia should sit on the sidelines and do nothing regarding the enlargement process has decreased. From 2023, when that percentage was 29 percent, it is now 21, that is, eight percentage points fewer citizens think that Macedonia should do nothing and not be active in this challenge, but that our country, state and Government should be much more active in the area of European integration – says Troshanovski.

According to him, what is an interesting piece of data is that the EU continues to be considered the most important and most influential ally of the country and, in the context of current geopolitical upheavals, it is obvious that citizens are leaning towards the alternative or option in which they see the greatest security, safety and perspective. (28 January 2026)
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant increase in public support for EU membership in North Macedonia, reflecting a positive shift towards European integration, which is associated with improved security, safety, and prospects for the population. This has broad societal implications, promoting stability, cooperation, and democratic values in a geopolitically sensitive region. The study provides detailed, substantive data on public opinion trends, ethnic group perspectives, and perceived obstacles, indicating meaningful progress in a major political and social process.
articles.personality_title: Over 70% of North Macedonians now support joining the EU, study finds
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – North Macedonia has been working for years to join the European Union (EU), hoping to gain more security and better opportunities for its people. The country has faced challenges, including disagreements with neighboring countries and different opinions among its ethnic groups.

**What happened** – A new study by the Institute for Democracy – Societas Civilis in Skopje shows that 71 percent of North Macedonians support joining the EU. This is nearly 10 percent more than last year. Support has grown especially among ethnic Macedonians, while ethnic Albanians still strongly support EU membership, though their support dropped slightly. The study also found that fewer people are unsure or uninterested in the topic.

**Impact** – This increase in support is important because it shows more people believe that joining the EU will bring security, safety, and better future prospects. It also means that fewer people want the country to stay inactive about EU membership. The EU remains seen as the most important ally, especially during times of political uncertainty in the region. However, some challenges remain, like disagreements with neighboring countries that slow down progress.

**What's next step** – The government and citizens will likely continue working on EU membership, trying to overcome obstacles and increase readiness. With more people supporting the process, there may be stronger pressure on leaders to push forward, including making constitutional changes that some ethnic groups support more than others.

**One-sentence takeaway** – More than 70 percent of North Macedonians now support joining the EU, marking a clear rise in hope and commitment toward European integration despite ongoing challenges.
articles.personality_title_fr: Plus de 70 % des Macédoniens du Nord soutiennent désormais l’adhésion à l’UE, selon une étude
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La Macédoine du Nord travaille depuis des années à rejoindre l’Union européenne (UE), espérant offrir plus de sécurité et de meilleures opportunités à sa population. Le pays fait face à des défis, notamment des désaccords avec ses voisins et des opinions différentes parmi ses groupes ethniques.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Une nouvelle étude de l’Institut pour la Démocratie – Societas Civilis à Skopje montre que 71 % des Macédoniens du Nord soutiennent l’adhésion à l’UE. C’est près de 10 % de plus que l’année dernière. Le soutien a particulièrement augmenté chez les Macédoniens ethniques, tandis que les Albanais ethniques restent très favorables, même si leur soutien a légèrement diminué. L’étude montre aussi que moins de personnes sont incertaines ou désintéressées.

**Impact** – Cette hausse du soutien est importante car elle montre que davantage de personnes pensent que rejoindre l’UE apportera sécurité, sûreté et de meilleures perspectives d’avenir. Elle signifie aussi que moins de citoyens veulent rester passifs sur cette question. L’UE reste perçue comme l’allié le plus important, surtout en période d’incertitude politique dans la région. Cependant, certains obstacles subsistent, comme les désaccords avec les pays voisins qui ralentissent les progrès.

**Prochaine étape** – Le gouvernement et les citoyens continueront probablement à travailler pour l’adhésion à l’UE, en essayant de surmonter les obstacles et d’accroître la préparation. Avec plus de soutien populaire, il pourrait y avoir une pression plus forte sur les dirigeants pour avancer, notamment sur des réformes constitutionnelles soutenues différemment selon les groupes ethniques.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Plus de 70 % des Macédoniens du Nord soutiennent désormais l’adhésion à l’UE, marquant une nette progression de l’espoir et de l’engagement vers l’intégration européenne malgré les défis en cours.
articles.personality_title_es: Más del 70 % de los macedonios del norte apoyan unirse a la UE, según estudio
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Macedonia del Norte ha estado trabajando durante años para unirse a la Unión Europea (UE), con la esperanza de lograr más seguridad y mejores oportunidades para su gente. El país ha enfrentado desafíos, incluyendo desacuerdos con países vecinos y diferentes opiniones entre sus grupos étnicos.

**Qué pasó** – Un nuevo estudio del Instituto para la Democracia – Societas Civilis en Skopje muestra que el 71 % de los macedonios del norte apoyan unirse a la UE. Esto es casi un 10 % más que el año pasado. El apoyo ha crecido especialmente entre los macedonios étnicos, mientras que los albaneses étnicos siguen apoyando fuertemente la adhesión, aunque su apoyo bajó un poco. El estudio también encontró que menos personas están indecisas o indiferentes.

**Impacto** – Este aumento en el apoyo es importante porque muestra que más personas creen que unirse a la UE traerá seguridad, protección y mejores perspectivas para el futuro. También significa que menos personas quieren que el país se quede inactivo respecto a la adhesión. La UE sigue siendo vista como el aliado más importante, especialmente en tiempos de incertidumbre política en la región. Sin embargo, hay desafíos, como desacuerdos con países vecinos que retrasan el progreso.

**Próximo paso** – El gobierno y los ciudadanos probablemente seguirán trabajando para unirse a la UE, intentando superar obstáculos y aumentar la preparación. Con más apoyo, puede haber una presión mayor sobre los líderes para avanzar, incluyendo cambios constitucionales que algunos grupos étnicos apoyan más que otros.

**Resumen en una frase** – Más del 70 % de los macedonios del norte apoyan unirse a la UE, mostrando un aumento claro en la esperanza y compromiso hacia la integración europea pese a los desafíos actuales.

articles.title: Rokas: It is necessary to achieve unity in the country to overcome the obstacles to EU accession
articles.summary: If internal unification happens, the other obstacles will be overcome - said Rokas
articles.content:
Skopje – The door of the European Union is wide open. There is full support for North Macedonia to join the EU and I believe that at this moment it is necessary for the country to unite – the Government, the opposition, the Parliament, civil society, businesses and young people to be pragmatic in accelerating the reforms, said today the EU ambassador in the country, Mihail Rokas.

At the promotion of the two research papers, “Analysis of Public Opinion on the Accession of North Macedonia to the European Union (2014 – 2025)” and “New Global Uncertainties, Old European Obligations: Public Opinion on EU Accession in 2025” in the Parliament, he expressed his conviction that although the survey showed that citizens believe that the external factor is an obstacle to joining the Union, if internal unification happens, the other obstacles will be overcome.

– I guarantee you that if this happens, regardless of what citizens think about there being problems, the obstacles to accession will be overcome. Not only must action be taken immediately and it is not just an opportunity that should be used, but the timing is right as well. We cannot compare this year and last year with the situations five or six or four years ago – said Rokas, emphasizing that now the question is how to build partnership, trust and whom to trust.

He expressed satisfaction that, according to the analysis, the EU is the partner with the greatest trust.

– I hope that with the effort we will jointly invest this year we will have even better results next year, not only in the survey but also from a pragmatic aspect in terms of the country’s movement towards the EU – said Rokas.

Comparing the research with that of last year, he emphasized that the results provide a great incentive, that is, the percentage of the population that is “for” joining the Union has increased by 10 percent, from 61 to 71 percent.

– Support from young people is greater. It is very important that young people also support it, that is, young people show that this is the future. It is a boost that the gap between different ethnicities or the participation of political parties is narrowing, there is a smaller divide. Everyone is “for” the EU. We note that citizens also reflect the priorities of the EU growth plan and the reform agenda, specifically the protection of the environment, but also judicial reforms and the fight against corruption – emphasized Rokas.

According to him, a great incentive is that the European Union continues to be a trusted partner of the country, an economic partner and the main donor.

– A very big incentive for us is the finding that citizens believe that the country will enter the EU has risen from only 17 to over 30 percent – added Rokas. (28 January 2026)
articles.reasoning: The article reports on increased public support and unity efforts in North Macedonia towards EU accession, which promises broad societal benefits including democratic reforms, judicial improvements, anti-corruption measures, and environmental priorities. This represents a meaningful political and social progress with significant positive impact for the country's future and its citizens.
articles.personality_title: North Macedonia sees growing unity and support for EU membership
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – North Macedonia has been working for years to join the European Union (EU). This process requires the country to make important changes and reforms. Public opinion and political unity play a big role in moving forward.

**What happened** – On January 28, 2026, the EU ambassador to North Macedonia, Mihail Rokas, spoke about new research showing stronger public support for joining the EU. He said the country needs unity among the government, opposition, civil society, businesses, and young people to speed up reforms. The research revealed that 71% of people now support EU membership, up from 61% the previous year.

**Impact** – This increase in support is important because it shows that more citizens believe in the benefits of joining the EU. It also highlights growing trust in the EU as a partner. The research found that people want progress on protecting the environment, improving the courts, and fighting corruption. Young people, in particular, show strong support, which is key for the country’s future.

**What’s next step** – The ambassador stressed that if different groups in North Macedonia unite and work together, the country can overcome obstacles to joining the EU. The focus will be on building trust and taking immediate action on reforms. Continued cooperation with the EU as a trusted partner will help the country move closer to membership.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Growing public support and unity in North Macedonia are creating a stronger path toward joining the European Union.
articles.personality_title_fr: La Macédoine du Nord voit un soutien et une unité croissants pour l'adhésion à l'UE
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La Macédoine du Nord travaille depuis des années pour rejoindre l'Union européenne (UE). Ce processus demande au pays de faire des changements et des réformes importantes. L'opinion publique et l'unité politique jouent un grand rôle pour avancer.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Le 28 janvier 2026, l'ambassadeur de l'UE en Macédoine du Nord, Mihail Rokas, a parlé de nouvelles recherches montrant un soutien public renforcé pour rejoindre l'UE. Il a dit que le pays doit s'unir, y compris le gouvernement, l'opposition, la société civile, les entreprises et les jeunes, pour accélérer les réformes. La recherche a révélé que 71 % des personnes soutiennent maintenant l'adhésion à l'UE, contre 61 % l'année précédente.

**Impact** – Cette augmentation du soutien est importante car elle montre que plus de citoyens croient aux avantages d'adhérer à l'UE. Elle souligne aussi une confiance croissante envers l'UE en tant que partenaire. La recherche a montré que les gens veulent des progrès dans la protection de l'environnement, l'amélioration des tribunaux et la lutte contre la corruption. Les jeunes, en particulier, montrent un fort soutien, clé pour l'avenir du pays.

**Prochaine étape** – L'ambassadeur a souligné que si les différents groupes en Macédoine du Nord s'unissent et travaillent ensemble, le pays pourra surmonter les obstacles à l'adhésion à l'UE. L'accent sera mis sur la construction de la confiance et la prise de mesures immédiates sur les réformes. La coopération continue avec l'UE comme partenaire de confiance aidera le pays à se rapprocher de l'adhésion.

**Phrase clé** – Le soutien public croissant et l'unité en Macédoine du Nord créent un chemin plus fort vers l'adhésion à l'Union européenne.
articles.personality_title_es: Macedonia del Norte observa creciente unidad y apoyo para unirse a la UE
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Macedonia del Norte ha estado trabajando durante años para unirse a la Unión Europea (UE). Este proceso requiere que el país haga cambios y reformas importantes. La opinión pública y la unidad política son muy importantes para avanzar.

**Qué pasó** – El 28 de enero de 2026, el embajador de la UE en Macedonia del Norte, Mihail Rokas, habló sobre una nueva investigación que muestra un mayor apoyo público para unirse a la UE. Dijo que el país necesita unidad entre el gobierno, la oposición, la sociedad civil, las empresas y los jóvenes para acelerar las reformas. La investigación mostró que el 71 % de las personas ahora apoyan la adhesión a la UE, un aumento desde el 61 % del año anterior.

**Impacto** – Este aumento en el apoyo es importante porque muestra que más ciudadanos creen en los beneficios de unirse a la UE. También destaca una mayor confianza en la UE como socio. La investigación encontró que la gente quiere avances en la protección del medio ambiente, la mejora de los tribunales y la lucha contra la corrupción. Los jóvenes, en particular, muestran un fuerte apoyo, lo cual es clave para el futuro del país.

**Próximo paso** – El embajador enfatizó que si los diferentes grupos en Macedonia del Norte se unen y trabajan juntos, el país puede superar los obstáculos para unirse a la UE. El enfoque estará en construir confianza y tomar medidas inmediatas en las reformas. La cooperación continua con la UE como socio confiable ayudará al país a acercarse a la membresía.

**Frase clave** – El creciente apoyo público y la unidad en Macedonia del Norte están creando un camino más fuerte hacia la adhesión a la Unión Europea.
